citation.article-title: Lactobacillus tucceti sp. nov., a new lactic acid bacterium isolated from sausage.

p.s: Description of L. tucceti sp. nov.
L. tucceti (tuc.ce’ti L. gen. n. tucceti, isolated from sausage)

Cells are rod shaped, 3 μm length by 1 μm width, Gram-positive, catalase negative, non-spore forming and non-motile. L. tucceti grows better in MRS composed in the laboratory than in the commercially available medium and, after 3 days of incubation at 30 °C, colonies are small, circular, translucent and gray.
It grows at 13 and 37 °C but not at 4 or 45 °C.
Both d- and l-lactic acid are produced.
It is able to hydrolyze arginine and aesculin.

Strain produces acid from N-acetylglucosamine, l-fucose, d-glucose, d-fructose, d-maltose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, l-rhamnose and d-ribose, whereas the acid production is negative for d-adonitol, amygdalin, d-arabinose, l-arabinose, d-arabitol, l-arabitol, arbutin, d-cellobiose, dulcitol, erythritol, d-fucose, d-galactose, gentibiose, gluconate, 2-ketogluconate, 5-ketogluconate, glycerol, glycogen, inositol, d-lactose, melibiose, methyl α-d-glucoside, inuline, d-lyxose, methyl α-d-mannoside, d-melezitose, methyl β−xyloside, d-raffinose, salicine, d-sorbitol, l-sorbose, starch, d-sucrose, d-tagatose, d-turanose, xylitol, d-xylose, and l-xylose.
The type strain is R 19cT (=DSM 20183T=CECT 5920T), isolated from sausage by Reuter in 1970 [16].
